title: Graveyard
data:
A **graveyard** (also called a *crypt* or *morgue*) is a [special room](/wiki/Special_room "Special room") in *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")* that contains various [undead](/wiki/Undead "Undead"), [demons](/wiki/M2_DEMON "M2 DEMON"), and [corpses](/wiki/Corpse "Corpse") as well as [chests](/wiki/Chest "Chest"), [large boxes](/wiki/Large_box "Large box") and [graves](/wiki/Grave "Grave").

A **graveyard level** is a level where undead creatures are less likely to leave corpses - there is a 1⁄9 chance of an undead monster leaving a corpse if you kill it, and a 1⁄3 chance otherwise.[\[1\]](#cite_note-1)

[ ]

## Contents

- [1 List of graveyard levels](#List_of_graveyard_levels)

  - [1.1 Special levels with graveyards](#Special_levels_with_graveyards)
  - [1.2 Designated graveyard levels](#Designated_graveyard_levels)

- [2 Generation](#Generation)

- [3 Strategy](#Strategy)

- [4 Messages](#Messages)

- [5 References](#References)

## List of graveyard levels

All levels with a graveyard *room* are considered graveyard levels; a [headstone](/wiki/Headstone "Headstone") alone does not mark a level as a graveyard, nor does the presence of [bones](/wiki/Bones "Bones").

### Special levels with graveyards

- The [Valley of the Dead](/wiki/Valley_of_the_Dead "Valley of the Dead")
- [Orcus-town](/wiki/Orcus-town "Orcus-town")
- [Moloch's Sanctum](/wiki/Moloch%27s_Sanctum "Moloch's Sanctum")
- The home, locate and goal levels of the [Tourist quest](/wiki/Tourist_quest "Tourist quest")
- All levels of the [Priest quest](/wiki/Priest_quest "Priest quest")

### Designated graveyard levels

The following levels are designated as graveyard levels in the code, despite not necessarily having actual graveyards:

- The [Castle](/wiki/Castle "Castle")
- The top and bottom levels of the [Wizard of Yendor's Tower](/wiki/Wizard_of_Yendor%27s_Tower "Wizard of Yendor's Tower")
- Levels on which you have summoned [undead](/wiki/Undead "Undead") with the cursed [Book of the Dead](/wiki/Book_of_the_Dead "Book of the Dead") or [Bell of Opening](/wiki/Bell_of_Opening "Bell of Opening")

## Generation

In a regular rooms-and-corridors level of [dungeon level](/wiki/Dungeon_level "Dungeon level") 12 or below, a graveyard has a 1⁄6 chance of being generated assuming there are no other special rooms (i.e., [shops](/wiki/Shop "Shop"), [throne rooms](/wiki/Throne_room "Throne room"), [leprechaun halls](/wiki/Leprechaun_hall "Leprechaun hall"), [zoos](/wiki/Zoo "Zoo"), [temples](/wiki/Temple "Temple") or [beehives](/wiki/Beehive "Beehive")).

Graveyards are capable of generating major demons outside of [Gehennom](/wiki/Gehennom "Gehennom") - the chance of a demon generating as a graveyard monster is ([dungeon level](/wiki/Dungeon_level "Dungeon level") - 11)/(10\* [dungeon level](/wiki/Dungeon_level "Dungeon level")).[\[2\]](#cite_note-2)

## Strategy

[Wraiths](/wiki/Wraith "Wraith") are a common occurrence in graveyards, and their corpses are highly desirable; some players lure wraiths away from graveyard levels before killing them. Note that the [Castle](/wiki/Castle "Castle") is considered a graveyard level, making luring wraiths up from the Valley of the Dead more difficult.

## Messages

- You suddenly realize it is unnaturally quiet.  
  The \<hair> on the back of your \<neck> stands up.

  There is a graveyard on the level.

- The \<hair> on your \<head> seems to stand up.

  As above, while you are [hallucinating](/wiki/Hallucinating "Hallucinating").

- You have an uncanny feeling...

  You are entering a graveyard [between 01:00 and 23:59](/wiki/Time "Time").

- \<Run> away! \<Run> away!

  You are entering a graveyard between 00:00 and 00:59. Note that undead deal twice normal damage between these times.[\[3\]](#cite_note-3)

## References

1. [↑](#cite_ref-1) [src/mon.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 38](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/mon.c#L38)
2. [↑](#cite_ref-2) [src/mkroom.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 439](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/mkroom.c#L439)
3. [↑](#cite_ref-3) [src/mhitu.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 961](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/mhitu.c#L961)

[![This article has been updated to reflect NetHack 3.6.7. Click here for more information.](/images/f/f7/Nh367-icon.png)](/wiki/NetHackWiki:Next_version "This article has been updated to reflect NetHack 3.6.7. Click here for more information.")
html:
Graveyard

From NetHackWiki
Jump to navigation Jump to search

A graveyard (also called a crypt or morgue) is a special room in NetHack that contains various undead, demons, and corpses as well as chests, large boxes and graves.

A graveyard level is a level where undead creatures are less likely to leave corpses - there is a 1⁄9 chance of an undead monster leaving a corpse if you kill it, and a 1⁄3 chance otherwise.[1]

Contents

  • 1 List of graveyard levels
    • 1.1 Special levels with graveyards
    • 1.2 Designated graveyard levels
  • 2 Generation
  • 3 Strategy
  • 4 Messages
  • 5 References

List of graveyard levels

All levels with a graveyard room are considered graveyard levels; a headstone alone does not mark a level as a graveyard, nor does the presence of bones.

Special levels with graveyards

  • The Valley of the Dead
  • Orcus-town
  • Moloch's Sanctum
  • The home, locate and goal levels of the Tourist quest
  • All levels of the Priest quest

Designated graveyard levels

The following levels are designated as graveyard levels in the code, despite not necessarily having actual graveyards:

  • The Castle
  • The top and bottom levels of the Wizard of Yendor's Tower
  • Levels on which you have summoned undead with the cursed Book of the Dead or Bell of Opening

Generation

In a regular rooms-and-corridors level of dungeon level 12 or below, a graveyard has a 1⁄6 chance of being generated assuming there are no other special rooms (i.e., shops, throne rooms, leprechaun halls, zoos, temples or beehives).

Graveyards are capable of generating major demons outside of Gehennom - the chance of a demon generating as a graveyard monster is (dungeon level - 11)/(10* dungeon level).[2]

Strategy

Wraiths are a common occurrence in graveyards, and their corpses are highly desirable; some players lure wraiths away from graveyard levels before killing them. Note that the Castle is considered a graveyard level, making luring wraiths up from the Valley of the Dead more difficult.

Messages

You suddenly realize it is unnaturally quiet.
The <hair> on the back of your <neck> stands up.
There is a graveyard on the level.
The <hair> on your <head> seems to stand up.
As above, while you are hallucinating.
You have an uncanny feeling...
You are entering a graveyard between 01:00 and 23:59.
<Run> away! <Run> away!
You are entering a graveyard between 00:00 and 00:59. Note that undead deal twice normal damage between these times.[3]

References

  1. ↑ src/mon.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 38
  2. ↑ src/mkroom.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 439
  3. ↑ src/mhitu.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 961
Retrieved from "https://nethackwiki.com/index.php?title=Graveyard&oldid=169270"

A '''graveyard''' (also called a ''crypt'' or ''morgue'') is a [[special room]] in ''[[NetHack]]'' that contains various [[undead]], [[M2_DEMON|demons]], and [[corpse]]s as well as [[chest]]s, [[large box]]es and [[grave]]s. A '''graveyard level''' is a level where undead creatures are less likely to leave corpses - there is a {{frac|9}} chance of an undead monster leaving a corpse if you kill it, and a {{frac|3}} chance otherwise.{{refsrc|src/mon.c|38|version=NetHack 3.6.7}} ==List of graveyard levels== All levels with a graveyard ''room'' are considered graveyard levels; a [[headstone]] alone does not mark a level as a graveyard, nor does the presence of [[bones]]. ===Special levels with graveyards=== * The [[Valley of the Dead]] * [[Orcus-town]] * [[Moloch's Sanctum]] * The home, locate and goal levels of the [[Tourist quest]] * All levels of the [[Priest quest]] ===Designated graveyard levels=== The following levels are designated as graveyard levels in the code, despite not necessarily having actual graveyards: * The [[Castle]] * The top and bottom levels of the [[Wizard of Yendor's Tower]] * Levels on which you have summoned [[undead]] with the cursed [[Book of the Dead]] or [[Bell of Opening]] ==Generation== In a regular rooms-and-corridors level of [[dungeon level]] 12 or below, a graveyard has a {{frac|6}} chance of being generated assuming there are no other special rooms (i.e., [[shop]]s, [[throne room]]s, [[leprechaun hall]]s, [[zoo]]s, [[temple]]s or [[beehive]]s). Graveyards are capable of generating major demons outside of [[Gehennom]] - the chance of a demon generating as a graveyard monster is ([[dungeon level]] - 11)/(10* [[dungeon level]]).{{refsrc|src/mkroom.c|439|version=NetHack 3.6.7}} ==Strategy== [[Wraith]]s are a common occurrence in graveyards, and their corpses are highly desirable; some players lure wraiths away from graveyard levels before killing them. Note that the [[Castle]] is considered a graveyard level, making luring wraiths up from the Valley of the Dead more difficult. ==Messages== {{message|You suddenly realize it is unnaturally quiet.
The on the back of your stands up.|There is a graveyard on the level.}} {{message|The on your seems to stand up.|As above, while you are [[hallucinating]].}} {{message|You have an uncanny feeling...|You are entering a graveyard [[time|between 01:00 and 23:59]].}} {{message| away! away!|You are entering a graveyard between 00:00 and 00:59. Note that undead deal twice normal damage between these times.{{refsrc|src/mhitu.c|961|version=NetHack 3.6.7}}}} ==References== {{nethack-367}} [[Category:Special rooms]]
